tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
this got really sad really fast
summary: All the times Bran talks about becoming a knight
body:
All the times Bran talks about becoming a knight

“Bran was going to be a knight himself someday, one of the Kingsguard. Old Nan said they were the finest swords in all the realm. There were only seven of them, and they wore white armor and had no wives or children, but lived only to serve the king. Bran knew all the stories. Their names were like music to him. Serwyn of the Mirror Shield. Ser Ryam Redwyne. Prince Aemon the Dragonknight. The twins Ser Erryk and Ser Arryk, who had died on one another’s swords hundreds of years ago, when brother fought sister in the war the singers called the Dance of the Dragons. The White Bull, Gerold Hightower. Ser Arthur Dayne, the Sword of the Morning. Barristan the Bold.” - Bran II, AGoT

“Broken, Bran thought bitterly as he clutched his knife. Is that what he was now? Bran the Broken? “I don’t want to be broken,” he whispered fiercely to Maester Luwin, who’d been seated to his right. “I want to be a knight.” - Bran VI, AGoT

“Bran stared resentfully at the sweating boys below. “If I still had my legs, I could beat them all.” He remembered the last time he’d held a sword in his hand, when the king had come to Winterfell. It was only a wooden sword, yet he’d knocked Prince Tommen down half a hundred times. “Ser Rodrik should teach me to use a poleaxe. If I had a poleaxe with a big long haft, Hodor could be my legs. We could be a knight together.” - Bran VII, AGoT

“The White Harbor lordlings would emerge later in the morning, with their knights and men-at-arms. Until then, the yard belonged to their squires, who ranged in age from ten to forty. Bran wished he were one of them so badly that his stomach hurt with the wanting.” - Bran II, ACoK

“I want to be a knight. Bran took another sip of the spiced honey wine from his father’s goblet, grateful for something to clutch. The lifelike head of a snarling direwolf was raised on the side of the cup. He felt the silver muzzle pressing against his palm, and remembered the last time he had seen his lord father drink from this goblet.” - Bran III, ACoK

“Bran was almost afraid to sit to supper that night, but when he did, it was pigeon pie they set before him. Everyone else was served the same, and he couldn’t see that anything was wrong with the food they served the Walders. Maester Luwin has the truth of it, he told himself. Nothing bad was coming to Winterfell, no matter what Jojen said. Bran was relieved … but disappointed too. So long as there was magic, anything could happen. Ghosts could walk, trees could talk, and broken boys could grow up to be knights. “But there isn’t,” he said aloud in the darkness of his bed. “There’s no magic, and the stories are just stories.” - Bran IV, ACoK

“I don’t want it. I want to be a knight.” - Bran V, ACoK

“Bran knew that feeling well enough. When he’d been little, all he had ever dreamed of was being a knight. But that had been before he fell and lost his legs.” - Bran II, ASoS

“Bran shook his head. The day was growing old by then, and long shadows were creeping down the mountainsides to send black fingers through the pines. If the little crannogman could visit the Isle of Faces, maybe I could too. All the tales agreed that the green men had strange magic powers. Maybe they could help him walk again, even turn him into a knight. They turned the little crannogman into a knight, even if it was only for a day, he thought. A day would be enough.” - Bran II, ASoS

“One day I will be like him. The thought filled Bran with dread. Bad enough that he was broken, with his useless legs. Was he doomed to lose the rest too, to spend all of his years with a weirwood growing in him and through him? Lord Brynden drew his life from the tree, Leaf told them. He did not eat, he did not drink. He slept, he dreamed, he watched. I was going to be a knight, Bran remembered. I used to run and climb and fight. It seemed a thousand years ago.” - Bran III, ADwD

“What was he now? Only Bran the broken boy, Brandon of House Stark, prince of a lost kingdom, lord of a burned castle, heir to ruins. He had thought the three-eyed crow would be a sorcerer, a wise old wizard who could fix his legs, but that was some stupid child’s dream, he realized now. I am too old for such fancies, he told himself. A thousand eyes, a hundred skins, wisdom deep as the roots of ancient trees. That was as good as being a knight. Almost as good, anyway.” - Bran III, ADwD

blog.name: turtle-paced
blog.title: turtle-paced
blog.description: Writing at the speed of the race course paradox.

summary: Hello turtle paced!  Is not strange bran is so focused about telling Jon his origins? Given it will be a shock if I was bran  I...
question: Hello turtle paced!  Is not strange bran is so focused about telling Jon his origins? Given it will be a shock if I was bran  I could consider avoid  my loving brother a so big sorrow. Moreover  how this revelation helps all against the walkers ? Sure it does not help with the northern lords. Bye
answer:
Jon’s Targaryen heritage could provide the forces of the living with another dragonrider, which is definitely a benefit for them all. 

I also understand why someone would feel compelled to reveal the truth to Jon - not from politics but from love. Jon has wanted to know who his mother was all his life. In the show, Ned promised to tell him and talk to him about it, and Jon was deprived of that opportunity. Even if the truth is hard for Jon to hear, that doesn’t mean he shouldn’t get to hear it.

This is assuming, however, Bran’s acting from a place of love rather than functioning as a plot device again. The show has done very poorly by this character. (What, is he not in the trailer because the wheelchair would ruin the ~aesthetic~? Or are we just being open about the fact that Bran’s been demoted from character status now?)

◸answered asks◿

tags: bran has a very typical hero's journey
and he is NOT a robot who isnt interested in the people around him
if that's your characterisation of bran; you're wrong
i am not a bran fanblog... so i can't reallyhelp you with any metas on themes and arcs in bran's journey
he is NOT night king or a feeling-less robot
summary: Bran is not a Stark anymore. He's the Night King, and he has no claims over Winterfell. There were dozens of ways to include him...
question: Bran is not a Stark anymore. He's the Night King, and he has no claims over Winterfell. There were dozens of ways to include him without ruining the 'aesthetic'. Like, I agree that ableism is a problem but I think you guys are barking up to wrong tree here.
answer:
Imo Bran’s got an interesting storyline bc it diverges from normal fantasy stuff. I love Arya, but what she went through is a giant trope. But Bran? His whole journey was very weird, and the fact he wasn’t truly interested in any of it makes it even more peculiar. I honestly can’t wait to see what’s going to happen with him. 

I feel like you and I are talking entirely different languages. I’m trying to give you the benefit of the doubt, but how is Bran not a Stark??

umm… friendly reminder that all of the stark kids have rejected their stark identity at some point or the other (“I am Alayne, Father. Who else would I be?” / “No one. I am no one. Just a blind girl, just a servant of Him of Many Faces.” / “Yes,“ he said, hesitantly, "kings have legitimized bastards before, but… I am still a brother of the Night’s Watch. I knelt before a heart tree and swore to hold no lands and father no children.”)

So, unless all of them are no longer Starks… Bran is still a Stark.

More importantly, Bran is the Night King?!?!?! WHEN?!?!? When did this happen? So, next season is going to be just Night King Bran versus. the original Night King? What are you talking about?

I am confused.

Ableism is a problem, but as long as the show-runners are doing it, don’t take it to heart and stop barking up the wrong tree… is a very weird defense. I genuinely don’t know how to respond to that.

Bran has a very typical fantasy trope development, as far as I know.

A young lord/prince, who wanted to be a knight, but tragedy befalls him, an he can’t remain in status quo, and has to go out of his comfort zone (winterfell) and he goes on a quest for knowledge, that will ultimately allow him to save the world…..   like, this is the TYPICAL HERO’S JOURNEY, if I am not mistaken.

Also, if your idea of an exciting character arc is someone go through a journey while the said character is not at all being interested or invested in it…. uh, I don’t know how to help you.

 So, in short

reblog.comment:
Imo Bran’s got an interesting storyline bc it diverges from normal fantasy stuff. I love Arya, but what she went through is a giant trope. But Bran? His whole journey was very weird, and the fact he wasn’t truly interested in any of it makes it even more peculiar. I honestly can’t wait to see what’s going to happen with him. 

I feel like you and I are talking entirely different languages. I’m trying to give you the benefit of the doubt, but how is Bran not a Stark??

umm… friendly reminder that all of the stark kids have rejected their stark identity at some point or the other (“I am Alayne, Father. Who else would I be?” / “No one. I am no one. Just a blind girl, just a servant of Him of Many Faces.” / “Yes,“ he said, hesitantly, "kings have legitimized bastards before, but… I am still a brother of the Night’s Watch. I knelt before a heart tree and swore to hold no lands and father no children.”)

So, unless all of them are no longer Starks… Bran is still a Stark.

More importantly, Bran is the Night King?!?!?! WHEN?!?!? When did this happen? So, next season is going to be just Night King Bran versus. the original Night King? What are you talking about?

I am confused.

Ableism is a problem, but as long as the show-runners are doing it, don’t take it to heart and stop barking up the wrong tree… is a very weird defense. I genuinely don’t know how to respond to that.

Bran has a very typical fantasy trope development, as far as I know.

A young lord/prince, who wanted to be a knight, but tragedy befalls him, an he can’t remain in status quo, and has to go out of his comfort zone (winterfell) and he goes on a quest for knowledge, that will ultimately allow him to save the world…..   like, this is the TYPICAL HERO’S JOURNEY, if I am not mistaken.

Also, if your idea of an exciting character arc is someone go through a journey while the said character is not at all being interested or invested in it…. uh, I don’t know how to help you.

 So, in short

I am confused.

Also, if your idea of an exciting character arc is someone go through a journey while the said character is not at all being interested or invested in it…. uh, I don’t know how to help you.

summary: starklings names:  brandon “bran” stark: mythic. brandon “bran the builder” stark is a legendary figure from the age of heroes....
body:
starklings names:

brandon “bran” stark:

mythic. brandon “bran the builder” stark is a legendary figure from the age of heroes. he is the founder of house stark and builder of winterfell as well as several other key structures (allegedly). its the classic name for stark kings. 

jon snow:

common. its like the jon smith of westeros. it doesnt get less noble than that. however his true name is aegon targaryen (I GUESS???) which has significant historical value. its a name for conquerors and kings. 

arya stark

unique. there’s only one arya stark. arya’s first name is taken from her great great grandmother who was a flint. but among the starks arya is the first to bear that name (officially). arya isn’t following in anyone’s footsteps. she’s one of a kind.

summary: the got fandom: bran isn’t in the teaser because he ‘died’/wheelchairs can’t access the crypts/it’s his vision the truth: it’s...
body:
the got fandom: bran isn’t in the teaser because he ‘died’/wheelchairs can’t access the crypts/it’s his vision

the truth: it’s ableism. they could have included him at any point but chose not to because they’re ableist.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
Bran: Well, some of you will probably die this season.
Sansa: Some of us? You're not included?
Bran: Precisely.
Jon: Explain,...
body:
Bran: Well, some of you will probably die this season.

Sansa: Some of us? You’re not included?

Bran: Precisely.

Jon: Explain, please.

Bran: Because they’re called the white WALKERS.

Arya: he does have a point.
